markers.label: Filler word: 'uh'
markers.feedback: This is a very minor filler word and doesn't disrupt your flow. To sound even more polished, try taking a short, silent breath when you feel a filler word coming on.

markers.label: Unsupported point
markers.feedback: You make a great point about not starting a speech with something about yourself, but you immediately move to the next tip without explaining the reasoning. To make your argument even more compelling, try to provide a brief 'why' for each tip you introduce.

markers.label: Reduced pitch variation
markers.feedback: In this section, where you're making a factual statement about your own speaking style ("I say um all the time..."), your pitch range narrows slightly. While effective for a matter-of-fact tone, introducing a bit more melodic variation could make this personal admission even more engaging and relatable.

markers.label: Clasped Hands (Fig Leaf Posture)
markers.feedback: You have wonderful, expressive gestures! When you're between points, try letting your hands rest at your sides instead of clasping them. This maintains an open and confident posture throughout.

transcript: People often ask me for tips on how they can become better public speakers. Many are actually quite surprised by my answers, because I tell them to do things that are the complete opposite to what most traditional speaking uh coaches advise. I don't tell people to start with something about themselves, for example. I tell people never to use big words. They make you sound arrogant and it makes it harder to connect with people. And one of the things that really annoys traditional speaking coaches is I tell people that it's totally fine to say um or ah. I say um all the time. Go watch any of the talks I've ever given, I say um constantly. But it makes me sound more human. Great presenters aren't the ones with the most energy. They're the ones that know how to connect to people in front of them.
